noun.description: A plane figure with four equal straight sides and four right angles.
An open (typically four-sided) area surrounded by buildings in a town, village, or city.
The product of a number multiplied by itself.
examples: a circle's area is proportional to the square of its radius

noun.description: An L-shaped or T-shaped instrument used for obtaining or testing right angles.
A person considered to be old-fashioned or boringly conventional in attitude or behavior.

adjective.description: Having the shape or approximate shape of a square.
Denoting a unit of measurement equal to the area of a square whose side is of the unit specified.
examples: 30,000 square feet of new gallery space
these lines must be square to the top and bottom marked edges
place one piece of wood on top of the other, ensuring that they are exactly square

adjective.description: (of two people) owing nothing to each other.
examples: an acknowledgment that we are square
it hit me square in the forehead

verb.description: Make square or rectangular; give a square or rectangular cross section to.
examples: you can square off the other edge
I'm able to square my profession with my religious beliefs
they're anxious to square their books before the audit

verb.description: Bring (one's shoulders) into a position in which they appear square and broad, typically to prepare oneself for a difficult task or event.
examples: chin up, shoulders squared, she stepped into the room

verb.description: Secure the help, acquiescence, or silence of (someone), especially by offering an inducement.
Set (a yard or other part of a ship) approximately at right angles to the keel or other point of reference.
(of a planet) have a square aspect with (another planet or position)
examples: Saturn squares the Sun on the 17th

phrases: It is the same knee problem as before and it looks as if it is back to square one for him, said Lehmann.
I think that the prosecution and the police have gone back to square one.
He made his comeback a year later but after 12 games he was back to square one.
In 1999 we lost all of our good players and went back to square one.
Having spent all summer to earn money to put yourself through college, Christmas comes and goes and you find yourself back to square one.
don't you worry, we'll get things squared away
One more championship will square it away for me.
Ibarra will get some money back, he explains, but it won't be the full amount and it won't be until the accounting is squared away.
So we took matters into our own hands and booked another flight ourselves, figuring that we could square things away with ATA after we got back home.
I'm sure it will be fine with my father, but I'll give you his number so you can square it away with him.
origin: Middle English: shortening of Old French esquare (noun), esquarre (past participle, used as an adjective), esquarrer (verb), based on Latin quadra square.
